Comment: It's way more than just a washing machine- utility providers often defer to energystar when picking products that receive incentives (and not just federal incentives, most set their own based on avoided costs and use their own money to pay for them). It's a good way to have a line into independent performance testing without doing it yourself. RIP small utilities on this one.   Several states also rely on the Portfolio Manager database to track building energy use in a standardized and low cost way- some of them even require it in statute. I spent all day working in Portfolio manager to do energy analyses for public facilities.   Source: my job uses energystar products and used to consult with EPA about new tech.

Comment: That's not true.  While there may be some examples of cutting corners to meet requirements, for the most part meeting the requirements means doing things that would contribute to longevity.  Here are some examples:  * Improving the insulation on things like refrigerators results in less compressor wear.   * Variable speed motors reduce wear and produce less heat. * Variable speed compressors reduce wear, heat and produce more consistent cycles. * Transition to solid-state controls resulting in smarter (and thus less) usage. * Environment sensitive dimming reduces burn on televisions * Use of LED lights, which last longer and produce significantly less heat. * Better auto-off and standby modes result in less use/burn.  These are just some of the things.  You said in another comment "parts have to get lighter to get more efficient".  That's not necessarily true, but lighter isn't necessarily less strong/reliable, and using more energy to move something heavier tends to have a negative impact on longevity.  Further, if it's longevity that you want, we could look at what other countries have done where longer warranties are mandated.

Comment: What's depressing is that in most areas of the country, the energy companies are perfectly fine with lower energy usage because they're near capacity anyway. That extra $40 billion/year wouldn't just be free money for them - it means that they'll be above maximum capacity, which will force them to spend a lot more than that to upgrade their grids and build additional power plants to cover the increased demand. Electric companies are actually pretty OK with programs like Energy Star because they know just how much it saves them in upgrading their systems. Honestly, I feel like this is less of a move to make energy companies happy and more of a move to destroy the US because in 5 years we're going to be dealing with rolling blackouts because the system can't keep up with demand...

Comment: There's such a thing as "diminishing returns."  Return on investment doesn't scale linearly with input; "we return $350 for every $1" doesn't mean that if you put in one more dollar you'll get $350 back, it means we're getting back $350 for every dollar we spend right now  One *might* credibly argue that the program is either over– or under–funded, but Trump is talking about canceling it entirely which is clearly, objectively incorrect
Author: Silvermoon3467

Comment: If I spend $10 on a multi-meter and go around my home checking energy use of appliances to figure out if anything is particularly inefficient, and that lets me be more efficient with energy use and I save $100 on energy bills this year, I got a 10:1 return on investment.     10:1 returns are great, let's spend more!  If I instead blow $100 buying a pro-level high-precision multimeter, my measurements are more precise... but they were basically good enough anyway, maybe I can make slightly better decisions and save $110 but now my return on investment is 1.1:1 because the money was spent unwisely.    If I instead blow $200 buying 20x $10 multimeters, I can still only cut my energy usage by $100 because I just plain have no use for the other 19 devices. So that money was just wasted and I only have a 0.5:1 return. Or you could look at it as the same 10:1 return on the first $10 and then I just threw away $190 because buying more of something I already have enough of is useless.
Author: AngryT-Rex

Comment: Trump is a fucking moron, but he originally got the talking point from anthracite coal. It's rare, with the biggest deposits in the world located in PA, but it has a higher carbon content and burns more efficiently with less particulate emissions than all other coal. If you know about Centralia, the fire under the town has been burning through anthracite deposits for over 60 years. Anthracite has more CO2 emissions because of the high carbon content, but less other pollutants when burned compared to other fossil fuels. While there are a bunch of bullshit studies created by the coal industry to support this "clean coal", which is where Trump got the term, there is enough evidence to suggest that it's at least comparable to other fossil fuels in it's ultimate environmental impact when you account for things like extraction methods, refining byproducts, transportation, leaks for oil and natural gas, etc...  All that being said, Trump is still a moron, and there's absolutely no reason that we should be expanding fossil fuel use again when we have cheaper, renewable, environmentally friendly options finally getting off the ground in a big way in the last few years.

Comment: You're not wrong, but I think the point that you are missing here is that clean coal isn't clean at all, it's just *cleaner* than standard coal processing. But the terminology fools people into thinking that it's actually clean on its face, and not just relative to historical processing methods.  It causing relatively the same amount of pollution as other fossil fuels is a win for *coal*, but it isn't a win for clean energy, particularly when proponents of clean coal represent it as the latter rather than the former.
